problems.title: Recycling Center
problems.statementHtml: In the recycling center, there are nn trash bags, the ii-th bag has a weight of aiai. At each second, two actions will happen successively:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤10001≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and cc (1≤n≤301≤n≤30, 1≤c≤109)1≤c≤109).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤1091≤ai≤109) — the weight of each trash bag.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, you must output a single integer — the minimum number of coins you have to spend to destroy all trash bags.
problems.noteHtml:
In the following explanation:

  • Numbers in blue represent trash bags that have been destroyed for free,
  • Numbers in red represent trash bags that have been destroyed for 11 coin,
  • Numbers in black represent trash bags that have not been destroyed yet.

In the first test case, one solution is:

  • [10,4,15,1,8][10,4,15,1,8]
  • [10,8,30,2,16][10,8,30,2,16], 1010 is destroyed for free because 10≤1010≤10.
  • [10,8,60,4,32][10,8,60,4,32], 88 is destroyed for free because 8≤108≤10.
  • [10,8,120,8,32][10,8,120,8,32], 3232 is destroyed for 11 coin because 32>1032>10.
  • [10,8,240,8,32][10,8,240,8,32], 88 is destroyed for free because 8≤108≤10.
  • [10,8,240,8,32][10,8,240,8,32], 240240 is destroyed for 11 coin because 240>10240>10.

In total, you paid 22 coins, and we can prove it is optimal.

In the second test case, one solution is:

  • [1000000000,1000000000,1000000000][1000000000,1000000000,1000000000]
  • [1000000000,2000000000,2000000000][1000000000,2000000000,2000000000], 10000000001000000000 is destroyed for 11 coin because 1000000000>421000000000>42.
  • [1000000000,2000000000,4000000000][1000000000,2000000000,4000000000], 20000000002000000000 is destroyed for 11 coin because 2000000000>422000000000>42.
  • [1000000000,2000000000,4000000000][1000000000,2000000000,4000000000], 40000000004000000000 is destroyed for 11 coin because 4000000000>424000000000>42.

problems.title: Deque Process
problems.statementHtml:
We say that an array aa of size nn is bad if and only if there exists 1≤i≤n−41≤i≤n−4 such that one of the following conditions holds:

An array is good if and only if it's not bad. For example:

You're given a permutation∗∗ p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn.

You must perform nn turns. At each turn, you must remove either the leftmost or the rightmost remaining element in pp. Let qiqi be the element removed at the ii-th turn.

Choose which element to remove at each turn so that the resulting array qq is good. We can show that under the given constraints, it's always possible.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (5≤n≤1000005≤n≤100000) — the length of the array.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n, pipi are pairwise distinct) — elements of the permutation.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 200000200000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, you must output a string ss of length nn. For every 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n, at the ii-th turn:

  • si=Lsi=L means that you removed the leftmost element of pp
  • si=Rsi=R means that you removed the rightmost element of pp

We can show that an answer always exists. If there are multiple solutions, print any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the sequence RRRLLLLRRRLLLL results in q=[7,6,5,1,2,3,4]q=[7,6,5,1,2,3,4].

In the second test case, the sequence LLRRLLRRLLLRRLLRRL results in q=[1,3,2,4,6,8,5,7,9]q=[1,3,2,4,6,8,5,7,9].

samples.output:
RRRLLLL
LLRRLLRRL
LLLLLLLLLLLL
LLLLLL
LLLLL
LLLLLLLLL

problems.title: Leftmost Below
problems.statementHtml:
Consider an array a1,…,ana1,…,an. Initially, ai=0ai=0 for every ii.

You can do operations of the following form.

For example, if a=[6,8,2,1]a=[6,8,2,1] and you choose x=6x=6, then ii will be equal to 33 (since a1≥6a1≥6, a2≥6a2≥6, and a3<6a3<6) and aa will become [6,8,8,1][6,8,8,1].

You can do as many operations as you want. Can you reach a target array b1,…,bnb1,…,bn?
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (2≤n≤2000002≤n≤200000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤1091≤bi≤109).

The sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 200000200000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print YES if you can reach the target array and NO otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we can do the following sequence of operations:

  • we choose x=2x=2, aa becomes [2,0,0,0][2,0,0,0]
  • we choose x=2x=2, aa becomes [2,2,0,0][2,2,0,0]
  • we choose x=3x=3, aa becomes [5,2,0,0][5,2,0,0]
  • we choose x=4x=4, aa becomes [5,6,0,0][5,6,0,0]
  • we choose x=1x=1, aa becomes [5,6,1,0][5,6,1,0]
  • we choose x=1x=1, aa becomes [5,6,1,1][5,6,1,1]

In the second test case, we can prove there is no way to reach [3,1,2][3,1,2].

problems.title: Sum of LDS
problems.statementHtml:
You're given a permutation∗∗ p1,…,pnp1,…,pn such that max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2 for all 1≤i≤n−21≤i≤n−2.

Compute the sum of the length of the longest decreasing subsequence†† of the subarray [pl,pl+1,…,pr][pl,pl+1,…,pr] over all pairs 1≤l≤r≤n1≤l≤r≤n.

∗∗A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††Given an array bb of size |b||b|, a decreasing subsequence of length kk is a sequence of indices i1,…,iki1,…,ik such that:
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains a single integer nn (3≤n≤5000003≤n≤500000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers p1,p2,…,pnp1,p2,…,pn (1≤pi≤n1≤pi≤n, pipi are pairwise distinct).

It is guaranteed that max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2max(pi,pi+1)>pi+2 for all 1≤i≤n−21≤i≤n−2.

The sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 500000500000.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the sum over all subarrays of the length of its longest decreasing subsequence.
problems.noteHtml:
For any array aa, we define LDS(a)LDS(a) as the length of the longest decreasing subsequence of aa.

In the first test case, all subarrays are decreasing.

In the second one, we have

LDS([4])=LDS([3])=LDS([1])=LDS([2])=1LDS([4])=LDS([3])=LDS([1])=LDS([2])=1

LDS([4,3])=LDS([3,1])=2,LDS([1,2])=1LDS([4,3])=LDS([3,1])=2,LDS([1,2])=1

LDS([4,3,1])=3,LDS([3,1,2])=2LDS([4,3,1])=3,LDS([3,1,2])=2

LDS([4,3,1,2])=3LDS([4,3,1,2])=3

So the answer is 1+1+1+1+2+2+1+3+2+3=171+1+1+1+2+2+1+3+2+3=17.

problems.title: Submedians (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The only difference is that in this version, you are asked to find a subarray only for the maximum submedian.

You can make hacks only if both versions of the problem are solved.

An integer vv is a median of an array bb of length mm if and only if:

You're given an integer kk and an array a1,…,ana1,…,an of integers between 11 and nn.

An integer vv from 11 to nn is said to be a submedian if there exists at least one pair of indices (l,r)(l,r) such that

It can be proven that there always exists at least one submedian. Find the maximum submedian vmaxvmax and any corresponding pair of indices (l,r)(l,r).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤500001≤t≤50000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤k≤n≤3000001≤k≤n≤300000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 300000300000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output three integers vmaxvmax, ll, and rr — the maximum submedian vmaxvmax and the bounds of a subarray of length at least kk (r−l+1≥kr−l+1≥k) such that vmaxvmax is one of its medians.

If there are many solutions, you can print any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the subarrays of length at least k=3k=3 are

  • (l=1,r=3)(l=1,r=3): [4,1,2][4,1,2] whose only median is 22,
  • (l=2,r=4)(l=2,r=4): [1,2,4][1,2,4] whose only median is 22, and
  • (l=1,r=4)(l=1,r=4): [4,1,2,4][4,1,2,4] whose medians are 22, 33, and 44.

In the second test case, one possible output is (l=3,r=4)(l=3,r=4) whose medians are 22 and 33.

Note that it can be proven that no subarray of length at least 22 admits 44 or 55 as a median.

problems.title: Submedians (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The only difference is that in this version, you are asked to find a subarray for all submedians.

You can make hacks only if both versions of the problem are solved.

An integer vv is a median of an array bb of length mm if and only if:

You're given an integer kk and an array a1,…,ana1,…,an of integers between 11 and nn.

An integer vv from 11 to nn is said to be a submedian if there exists at least one pair of indices (l,r)(l,r) such that

Find all submedians and for each of them, find any corresponding pair of indices (l,r)(l,r).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤500001≤t≤50000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and kk (1≤k≤n≤3000001≤k≤n≤300000).

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n).

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 300000300000.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output your answer in the following format.

On the first line, output cc, the number of submedians.

On the ii-th of the following cc lines, output three integers vivi, lili, and riri such that

  • ri−li+1≥kri−li+1≥k, and
  • vivi is one of the medians of the subarray [ali,…,ari][ali,…,ari].

Each submedian should be reported exactly once, that is, integers v1,…,vcv1,…,vc must be pairwise distinct. The order in which they are reported does not matter.

If there are many solutions, you can print any of them.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the subarrays of length at least k=3k=3 are

  • (l=1,r=3)(l=1,r=3): [4,1,2][4,1,2] whose only median is 22,
  • (l=2,r=4)(l=2,r=4): [1,2,4][1,2,4] whose only median is 22, and
  • (l=1,r=4)(l=1,r=4): [4,1,2,4][4,1,2,4] whose medians are 22, 33, and 44.

In the second test case, one possible output is

  • (l=4,r=5)(l=4,r=5): [2,1][2,1] whose medians are 11 and 22,
  • (l=1,r=5)(l=1,r=5): whose only median is 22,
  • (l=3,r=4)(l=3,r=4): [3,2][3,2] whose medians are 22 and 33.

All of these subarrays are indeed of length at least 22. Note that it can be proven that no subarray of length at least 22 admits 44 or 55 as a median.

problems.title: Strict Triangle
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an undirected connected graph with nn nodes and mm edges. The weight wiwi of the ii-th edge is not yet decided and must be a real number between lili and riri.

You are given a node kk. Determine if there exists a valid assignment of weights (w1,…,wm)(w1,…,wm) such that:

∗∗Given an assignment of weights ww, distw(u,v)distw(u,v) is the minimum value of we1+we2+…+wepwe1+we2+…+wep over all sequences of pp edges (e1,e2,…,ep)(e1,e2,…,ep) that form a path from uu to vv.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤100001≤t≤10000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains three integers nn, mm, and kk (4≤n≤2000004≤n≤200000, n−1≤m≤200000n−1≤m≤200000, 2≤k≤n−12≤k≤n−1) — the number of nodes, the number of edges, and the node kk.

The ii-th of the following mm lines contains four integers uiui, vivi, lili, and riri (1≤ui,vi≤n1≤ui,vi≤n, ui≠viui≠vi, 1≤li≤ri≤1091≤li≤ri≤109), representing an edge between uiui and vivi whose weight must be between lili and riri inclusive. No edge appears in the input more than once.

It is guaranteed that:

  • the sum of nn over all test cases doesn't exceed 200000200000
  • the sum of mm over all test cases doesn't exceed 200000200000
problems.outputSpecHtml:
Print YES if there exists a valid assignment of weights and NO otherwise.

You can output the answer in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, w=(20,30,49,21)w=(20,30,49,21) is a valid assignment of weights, since distw(1,4)=70≠71=distw(1,2)+distw(2,4)distw(1,4)=70≠71=distw(1,2)+distw(2,4).

In the second test case, there is no valid assignment of weights.

samples.output:
YES
NO
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO

tutorial.contentHtml:
Thank you for participating in our round ! We hope you enjoyed our problems. Feel free to discuss them in the comment section :)

/!\ The solution codes will be available in a few minutes

UPD: The solution codes have been added ! UPD2: The solution codes links are fixed ! Sorry for the inconvenience.

2128A - Recycling Center

Solution

Let's say a bag is expensive if ai>c and free if ai≤c.

First, observe that as long as there is at least one free bag remaining, we should destroy a free bag. We will perform all expensive destructions at the end. The goal is to perform as much free destructions as possible.

When there are multiple free bags, which one to choose? The bigger a bag is, the less time you have to destroy it before it becomes expensive. Hence, at each second, you should destroy the biggest remaining free bag.

This process can be naively simulated in O(n2), which was sufficient under given constraints. If you sort the array beforehand and keep the current multiplier in a separate variable (instead of multiplying all weights), it can be done in O(nlogn) time.
